item.title: Ticket #1263 (Don't notify admins and post_authors of their own comments) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Admins (user_level >= 9), and post_authors who comment on their own post, should not be notified of their own comments.

item.title: Ticket #1262 (Admins and post author should never be moderated) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1262 (Admins and post author should never be moderated) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1262 (Admins and post author should never be moderated) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Regardless of the apparent spamminess of the comment, and regardless of moderation settings, comments made by site admins (user_level >= 9), and a post_author when commenting on their own post, should never be moderated.

item.title: Ticket #1261 (Remove svn:executable from streams.php and gettext.php) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1261 (Remove svn:executable from streams.php and gettext.php) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
There's no reason for streams.php and gettext.php having the executable bit set, svn:executable prop should be removed:

% find . -type f -perm +u+x | xargs svn pl Properties on 'wp-includes/streams.php':

svn:executable svn:keywords svn:eol-style

Properties on 'wp-includes/gettext.php':

svn:executable svn:keywords svn:eol-style

item.title: Ticket #1238 (DB optimizations) updated
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: Almost done with cleanup.

item.title: Ticket #1238 (DB optimizations) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Oops. Right you are. I misread. We need to do this in get_category() too then.

item.title: Ticket #1238 (DB optimizations) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
er, cat_ID and category_id will be in the cache, with 4. cat_ID is fetched twice, which produces close to zero overhead in sql. but i guess do as you see fit. i'm OK with everything as long as the cache is around for me to use in my plugins. ;)

speaking of plugins, there's this line in wp-blog-header.php

update_category_cache();

by tracing the queries I found it occurs after the 'init' hook, during which a plugin may potentially set the category cache.

Replacing with:

if ( !isset($cache_categories) )

update_category_cache();

could save a few cycles too. :)

item.title: Ticket #1238 (DB optimizations) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Currently, we need both cat_ID and category_id in the cache or things will break. I'd rather get rid of "as category_id" and fix the few places that use category_id to use cat_ID instead. Actually, for 1.5.1 I would rather just revert.

edited on: 04-19-05 16:16

item.title: Ticket #1258 (Curly quotes mixups) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1258 (Curly quotes mixups) created
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
I think there is a tiny problem in the wordpress text renduring:

when you use single quotes in the text, WP converts them to single fancy quotes. However, some quotes are transformed in the wrong direction.

e.g. if you type: 'products', 'services', you get â€˜productsâ€™, â€™servicesâ€™ rather than â€˜productsâ€™, â€˜servicesâ€™.

I think the problem comes from WP detecting something like /'s/ rather than /\w's/ â€™s

item.title: Ticket #1255 (moderation email) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: I get emailed when I have made a comment and get asked to moderate a comment that I have made. Surely the first post by an admin should be automatically authorised, and there's no need to send them an email to confirm they just wrote a message.

item.title: Ticket #1254 (add_ping() never called) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1254 (add_ping() never called) created
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
When pingbacks are sent, their information never gets stored in $wpdb->posts.pinged. Logging pingbacks show that all pingbacks produce IXR_Error(48, 'The pingback has already been registered.') _even when pingbacks are actually sent_.

This suggests that the pingback sending function is getting called twice: once when the pingback is sent, and once to test to see if a pingback has been sent (which, naturally, will always be the case).

item.title: Ticket #1252 (patch for next_post() and previous_post() to honor "same_category" ...) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Cool. Updated patch to latest SVN. Used get_the_category() to get the list of categories so that we make use of the cache. Updated previous_post() and next_post() to use get_previous_post() and get_next_post().
